title: Drill: Evaluation
description: If f(x) = x + 1, what is f(2)?
hints: Substitute 2 for x.

title: Drill: Injective Check
description: Is f(x) = x² injective on all Real numbers?
hints: Does f(-1) equal f(1)?

title: Drill: Domain
description: What is the one real number NOT in the domain of f(x) = 1/x?
hints: Division by zero is undefined.

title: Drill: Floor
description: What is floor(3.9)?
hints: Round down to the nearest integer.

title: Domain and Range
description: Find the domain and range of the function f(x) = x² where f: Z → Z (Z is integers).
hints: Domain is given in the definition.
Range is the set of possible outputs.
Can x² be negative?
solution:
Domain: Z (All integers, as defined).
Range: {0, 1, 4, 9, ...} (Perfect squares).
More formally: {y ∈ Z | ∃x ∈ Z, y = x²}.

title: Injectivity Check
description: Determine if f(x) = 2x + 1 is injective (one-to-one) on the real numbers R. Prove your answer.
hints: Assume f(x) = f(y).
Show that this implies x = y.
solution:
Assume f(x) = f(y).
2x + 1 = 2y + 1
Subtract 1: 2x = 2y
Divide by 2: x = y

Since f(x)=f(y) implies x=y, the function is Injective.

title: Surjectivity Check
description: Is f(x) = x² surjective (onto) from R to R? If not, restrict the codomain to make it surjective.
hints: Can you get output -1?
The range of x² is non-negative numbers.
solution:
No, it is not surjective onto R because negative numbers have no preimage (no real x exists such that x² = -1).
To make it surjective, restrict the codomain to [0, ∞) (non-negative reals).

title: Function Composition
description: Let f(x) = x + 1 and g(x) = 2x. Find (f ∘ g)(x) and (g ∘ f)(x). Are they the same?
hints: (f ∘ g)(x) means f(g(x)).
Plug g(x) into f.
solution:
(f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(2x) = 2x + 1.
(g ∘ f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(x + 1) = 2(x + 1) = 2x + 2.

They are NOT the same (2x + 1 ≠ 2x + 2).

title: Inverse Function
description: Find the inverse of f(x) = (x - 3) / 2.
hints: Swap x and y.
Solve for y.
solution:
y = (x - 3) / 2
Swap: x = (y - 3) / 2
Solve for y:
2x = y - 3
2x + 3 = y

Inverse function f⁻¹(x) = 2x + 3.

title: Floor and Ceiling
hints: Floor: Greatest integer less than or equal.
Ceiling: Smallest integer greater than or equal.
Be careful with negatives: -3 is less than -2.1.

title: Pigeonhole Principle (Functions)
description: If f: A → B and |A| > |B|, prove f cannot be injective.
hints: If you have more pigeons (A) than holes (B), what happens?
At least two elements of A must map to the same element of B.
solution:
By the Pigeonhole Principle, if we map |A| elements into |B| targets and |A| > |B|, at least two elements from A (say a1, a2) must map to the same target in B.
So f(a1) = f(a2) with a1 ≠ a2.
Therefore, f is not injective.

title: Recursion
description: A function is defined recursively: f(0) = 1, f(n) = n * f(n-1). What does this function compute? Calculate f(4).
hints: Trace the execution for small n.

title: Characteristic Function
description:
The characteristic function of a set A, denoted χ_A(x), is 1 if x ∈ A and 0 if x ∉ A.
Express χ_(A ∩ B)(x) in terms of χ_A(x) and χ_B(x).
hints: Intersection requires x to be in A AND x to be in B.
Look at multiplication.
solution:
χ_(A ∩ B)(x) = χ_A(x) · χ_B(x).

If x is in both, 1·1 = 1.
If x is missing from either, the product is 0.

title: Counting Functions
description: How many distinct functions are there from a set A with 3 elements to a set B with 4 elements?
hints: For each element in A, how many choices in B?
Are the choices independent?
solution:
Let A = {1, 2, 3}.
f(1) can be any of 4 values.
f(2) can be any of 4 values.
f(3) can be any of 4 values.

Total functions = 4 × 4 × 4 = 4³ = 64.

title: Partial Functions
description: The function f(x) = 1/x is a "partial function" from R to R. Why? How can we make it total?
hints: Is f defined for all real numbers?
Consider x = 0.
solution:
It is partial because f(0) is undefined, so 0 is in the domain R but has no mapping.
To make it total, we can either:
1. Remove 0 from the domain: f: R-{0} → R.
2. Define a value for f(0), e.g., f(0) = 0 (though this makes it discontinuous).

title: Increasing Functions
description: Prove that if f(x) is strictly increasing (x < y implies f(x) < f(y)), then f is injective.
hints: Injective means x ≠ y implies f(x) ≠ f(y).
If x ≠ y, then either x < y or y < x.
solution:
Proof:
Assume x ≠ y.
Case 1: x < y. Then f(x) < f(y), so f(x) ≠ f(y).
Case 2: y < x. Then f(y) < f(x), so f(x) ≠ f(y).
In all cases, distinct inputs yield distinct outputs.
Therefore, f is injective.

title: Lambda Notation
description:
In Computer Science, functions are often written as λx.E.
Evaluate (λx. x² + 1)(5).
hints: Substitute the argument (5) for the variable (x) in the expression.

title: Images and Preimages
description:
Let f: Z → Z, f(x) = x². 
(a) Find the Image of the set A = {-1, 0, 1, 2}.
(b) Find the Preimage of B = {4, 9}.
hints: Image: Apply f to every element in A.
Preimage: Find all x such that f(x) is in B.

title: Identity Function
description: Let id(x) = x. Prove that for any function f: A → B, f ∘ id_A = f.
hints: Evaluate (f ∘ id)(x) for any x in A.
id(x) returns x.
solution:
For any x ∈ A:
(f ∘ id_A)(x) = f(id_A(x)) = f(x).
Since the output is identical for all inputs, the functions are equal.

title: Well-Definedness
description: Let f: Q → Z be defined by f(p/q) = p + q. Is f well-defined?
hints: Rational numbers have multiple representations (e.g., 1/2 = 2/4).
Check if f(1/2) equals f(2/4).
solution:
f(1/2) = 1 + 2 = 3.
f(2/4) = 2 + 4 = 6.
Since 1/2 = 2/4 but f(1/2) ≠ f(2/4), the function gives different outputs for the same input.
Therefore, f is NOT well-defined.
